positive.review: Relaxing and fun, the perfect sequel to the first game. My only gripe is that I miss the workshop feature, I used it a lot in the first game. I even made a school that was fully stocked with products and toys as my final project in a child development class. But it's not the end of the world that it's absent as the quality of life improvements more than make up for it. Wonderful game, I recommend it.

House Flipper is a title that, probably, by surprise came to be a simulation title that is major and has a wide recognition. I have been waiting for House Flipper 2 for a long time. The last installment of the game offered me lots of fun hours, and I hoped for the sequel to do the same. House Flipper 2 is a flipping simulator created by a Polish company, Frozen District.

üß†We have to start somewhere, so at the beginning of the game we have to clean or repaint very neglected houses. This introduces a new element: unpacking clients boxes. This allows us to do our first decorating and learn how to arrange items, for example, on shelves, which can sometimes be problematic. We also get the chance to learn basic game functions thanks to instruction books left in various places in the clients' houses.

Originally simple tasks gradually evolve into increasingly complex and better paying ones. Through them, we build our reputation and can see how much work the developers put into the details. I'm most captivated by the stains left after a raccoon's visit, and then we complete the task by washing off its paw prints.

Tasks are rated on a scale of 1 to 3 stars. A big plus is that just one star is enough to complete the task, and that you don't need to complete the task 100% to earn all the stars. Perfectionists will appreciate the device that allows you to find every dirt and the smallest debris.

A major change and surprise are the phone calls we receive from customers during house inspections. We learn the caller's backstory and personality, which allows us to experience a modest plot that, in my opinion, changes the nature of this game. We no longer have impersonal orders; we clean the house of a celebrating band or an absent-minded artist. Of course, we don't have to answer the phone, which would be worthwhile sometimes.

Additional activities like window washing and appliance assembly add a bit of variety to the gameplay, but they could be a bit more elaborate. Self assembly is limited to a few clicks and possibly moving pipes. The store offers us some discounts in return, but I'm uncertain if it is worth it. The games per se are not so interesting and I experienced minigame loading times that were as long or longer than the whole game itself even though I had a good configuration. Fortunately, they can be skipped, which I often used.

House Flipper 2 changes the gameplay experience somewhat, after we've explored our capabilities and begun renovating on our own, enabled by the funds we've acquired. We purchase our first house and refine it to our tastes you can get a bit of a Sims vibe. For those who, like me, played the first version of the game, a major change is the decoration database and interior design options. Various architectural styles are now available, which in the original version were really limited to the most basic ones.

When we finish, we go back to our home, the house, which we got as an inheritance from our parents and which also needs a repainting. We can also here, let the fantasy take us and make it the house of our minds. Naturally, just like in the first simulation, we can sell the house and buy a different one.

For architecture fans, a completely new feature is available - sandbox mode. Thanks to it, we construct buildings from scratch, having the ability to fly and use all the game's tools. This is where the opportunity to share our projects with others comes in. We can boast about our building skills and create challenges similar to those in the game, involving cleaning up stains and clearing up trash.

‚úÖPros.
- The ability to build your own house
- A wide variety of architectural styles
- Freedom in choosing colors, patterns, and object placement
- Distinctive details
- Various orders

‚ùåCons.
- The need to throw garbage bags into trash cans is annoying, artificially lengthening the gameplay
- Minigames are not entirely successful and quickly become boring.
- The smaller the space you're working in, the more problems and bugs you encounter with movement and basic game functions.

üßæIn Conclusion.
Is House Flipper 2 a copy of the first game? Yes and no. I must admit that the second installment has brought a lot of variety and innovation, making it a truly enjoyable experience thanks in part to the flipping and new decorations. The game constantly calls for a bit more variety in the minigames and assembly elements, and for not artificially lengthening the gameplay we get a fun game that can last dozens of hours.
8/10üîö

TL;DR House Flipper 2 is a fun evolution on the original house flipper, with the introduction of co-op and the improvement of core systems adding to the original game's appeal. 

Gameplay: Similar to the first house flipper, the core loop for the early game is to take clearly defined jobs for customers. These usually demonstrate the mechanics of the game, and provide the player with the funds needed for the late game loop. This late game consists of buying wrecked houses, and flipping them for a profit. Similar to the first game, the player has a variety of tools, some focused on cleaning, others renovation, and still more on landscaping. These have been improved from the base game, especially the demo tool, which now feels a bit less tedious. Other features have remained mostly the same, with the window-cleaning and vacuuming both changing little. Overall, it works for the game, and provides an enjoyable experience. 

Graphics: The look of the game has improved markedly from House Flipper 1, but still has that distinct simulation game look. The lighting is now vastly improved, as are the textures, but in a muted way. The game looks conventionally good, but doesn't have much interesting in the way of an art style or standout graphics. However, it still looks pleasant. 

Story: The game has a small story to work on through assigned tasks and jobs. Each job will usually contain a phone call, which will demonstrate a fragment of the story, which largely concerns the town's discontent towards a large company renovating a historically significant building. It's interesting enough, and it does lead to a nice conclusion, but overall, it's a relatively minor part of the game. 

Bugs/Performance: Thankfully, House Flipper 2 both runs quite well, and is relatively free from bugs. At nearly 16 hours of playtime, I've encountered a bit of stuttering with the graphics maxed, and no bugs to speak of. Overall, quite well done.

I personally enjoy House Flipper 1 much more than the second game. The first game simply offered a richer and more complete experience overall. It had a wider variety of houses to flip, more furniture and style options, and a lot more DLC content to explore. The gardening aspect in House Flipper 1 was also much better, with more plants, tools, and customization options that made creating outdoor spaces just as fun as decorating the interiors. The mechanics in the original game felt smoother and more natural, especially the rooming system that allowed me to create and define specific rooms. That feature gave me full control over the design and made every project feel unique and personal.

In House Flipper 2, I really dislike how the assembly mechanic was separated into its own game mode instead of being integrated into regular gameplay. It breaks immersion and takes away from the flow of renovating houses. However, one thing House Flipper 2 does better is the addition of co-op mode, which allows me to play with my wife. Working together on projects is a lot of fun, even if the rest of the game feels like a step backward compared to the first one.

For now I will not be recommending this game, but maybe things will change in the future.

I want to give this game a good review so badly, as the first HF was a favorite of mine for a long time, and I was extremely excited for the second. Unfortunately, so far it seems all of the fears I had came true. The game doesn't feel complete, there's far less variety in the way of actual furniture or decor. Most of the features beloved from the first are only now being added in. It also seems as though it is going to have all the same DLCs, and likely more. 
I'm, personally, against the EA-style of putting out the same game, without making sure the add-ons from the previous version are in the base version. I do not want to have to buy another Halloween pack, a farming pack, a pet pack, a gardening pack, a luxury items pack, and so on. I already did with the previous game. I would absolutely jump at *actual* new DLCs, but knowing it's most likely going the route of "it's the same game but with better graphics so you have to buy every single thing all over again" makes me weary. As of right now, I can't recommend it over the first. Better visuals just isn't worth it to me.

I personally enjoy House Flipper 1 much more than the second game. The first game simply offered a richer and more complete experience overall. It had a wider variety of houses to flip, more furniture and style options, and a lot more DLC content to explore. The gardening aspect in House Flipper 1 was also much better, with more plants, tools, and customization options that made creating outdoor spaces just as fun as decorating the interiors. The mechanics in the original game felt smoother and more natural, especially the rooming system that allowed me to create and define specific rooms. That feature gave me full control over the design and made every project feel unique and personal.

In House Flipper 2, I really dislike how the assembly mechanic was separated into its own game mode instead of being integrated into regular gameplay. It breaks immersion and takes away from the flow of renovating houses. However, one thing House Flipper 2 does better is the addition of co-op mode, which allows me to play with my wife. Working together on projects is a lot of fun, even if the rest of the game feels like a step backward compared to the first one.

For now I will not be recommending this game, but maybe things will change in the future.
